Please using this api: Activity.setContentView.
Answer: The crash is likely due to a NullPointerException. This is because the views `gob1`, `gob2`, `lb`, `plb`, and `prb` are not initialized before being used. 

To fix this, you should initialize these views in the `onCreate` method of your `MainActivity` class. Here is an example of how you can do this:

```java
@Override
protected void onCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) {
    super.onCreate(savedInstanceState);
    setContentView(R.layout.activity_main); // Assuming you have a layout named activity_main

    gob1 = (Button) findViewById(R.id.gob1);
    gob2 = (Button) findViewById(R.id.gob2);
    lb = (Button) findViewById(R.id.lb);
    plb = (Button) findViewById(R.id.plb);
    prb = (Button) findViewById(R.id.prb);

    gob1.setOnClickListener(new View.OnClickListener(){
        @Override
        public void onClick(View p1) {
            // Your code here
        }
    });

    // Repeat for other buttons
}
```

In this code, replace `R.id.gob1`, `R.id.gob2`, etc. with the IDs of your buttons in your layout file. This code should be placed in the `onCreate` method of your `MainActivity` class.

Also, make sure that the IDs of your buttons in your layout file match the ones you use in your Java code. If they don't match, the `findViewById` method will return null and a NullPointerException will occur when you try to call methods on the views.

This should resolve your crash issue.

Note: The `setContentView` method should be called before initializing the views, as it sets the layout for the activity.

Please replace `R.layout.activity_main` with the correct layout file for your activity.

Also, ensure that the IDs of your buttons in your layout file match the ones you use in your Java code.

If you still encounter the crash, please provide more information about your layout files and any other relevant code.
